dialogues.text: PAM glancing through Jim's notebooks as they sit on his  sleeping bag with a lantern and bunsen burner, overlookin moon, ocean, scudding clouds and a vast forest of televis antennas. Fires burn from the beach. In the notebooks, at intervals during the conversation, w see powerful sketches colored in visionary hallucinogenic William Blake mode with writing between. Books are everyw panning Kerouac, Ginsberg, Nietzsche, Rimbaud, Mailer, Ar mythological works, shamanistic books, a library of stole ideas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading, looking) These are like beautiful! I never  read much poetry in school. I hated  it. What's a "shaman"? (mispronounces)

dialogues.text: Are you a "shaman"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh (pause) no. I just write about it. What turns  you on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Experience. Freedom.  Love... Now. Peyote's like love.  When it's given it's blessed. When  it's sold it's damned. I like peyote.  I like acid, it's easier to get. I  like the spiritual voyage. The first  time I did acid I saw God. I did. I  had a friend who was Christ. And he  was Judas too. I suddenly knew the  secret of everything -- that we're  all one, the universe is one. And  that everything is beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it? I don't know. I think you're  alive by confronting death -- by  experiencing pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're alive by recognizing  beauty -- seeing truth because when  you discover truth you discover what  love is... we're all saying the same  thing. It's "love me and I'll love  you."

dialogues.text: Do you love Death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think life hurts a lot more than  death. When you die the pain is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pam shivers, a strange thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do I look at you... and see my  death? (pause, shrugs) No, that's ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet your dad's a school teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was your father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Military

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you moved around a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, about 8 times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many sisters and brothers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One... she's the pretty one... I  love your neck. (she gets in his lap)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs his fingers thru her hair, kissing her gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...but one, the most beautiful one  of all dances in a ring of fire and  throws off the challenge with a shrug"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's beautiful. Who did you write  it for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wrote it for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The panties coming off. Rousseau dangling from the Venice moon. He moves a little over excited, nervous, more awkwa than we might expect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...take your time, Jim... there's no  hurry, I'm all you have to do  tonight...

dialogues.speaker: DOORS SONG
dialogues.text: Well the clock says it's time to close now  I guess I'd better go now...  As we depart the rooftop.  Your fingers weak with minarets  Speaking secret alphabets  I light another cigarette  Learn to forget, learn to forget, learn to forget

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Possibly we hear the soft backbeat of MOONLIGHT DRIVE wit lyrics. RAY MANZAREK is meditating in yoga posture, longer hair a well, in his post-graduate phase, sandals, colorful hippi shirt. But the meditation is not going well. He's shaking his head at himself, frowning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Om om... No bliss! No bliss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim has approached closer, amused, looking down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Ray, try acid man, it's  guaranteed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray opening his eyes -- his POV -- Jim, slouched, jacket  over his shoulder, sun behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Morrison... Aw shit. Last trip I  thought I was going through hell's  digestive system. Something painted  by Hieronymus Bosch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never had a bummer on acid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like naturally high man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever works. Making movies at MGM  yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I saw the head of production  and I said Godard doesn't use scripts,  he improvises with his camera and he  said, "great who's Godard?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) We gotta take the planet back,  reinvent the Gods, make new myths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right on. I thought you went to New  York?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never got there. Went out to the  desert and uh... got lost y'know.  Days. I been living on Trick's  rooftop. Got stuck on this chick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha been doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Writing. Poems. Songs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Songs? Lemme hear one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So neither can Dylan. "Johnny's in  the basement mixing up the medicine,  I'm on the pavement thinking about  the government". But he's got the  words man. That's what they want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly sings) Let's swim to the moon un hunh  Let's climb thru the tide  Penetrate the evening  That the city sleeps to hide

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim has crouched, digging his hand in the sand. As the gr spill out of his fist he has his eyes closed. Ray pantomimes chords in the keyboard sand. All of a sudd we're in RAY'S POV -- a mystical moment. Jim singing, no  sound, then pure song, unadulterated by atmosphere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's swim out tonight love  It's our turn to try  Parked beside the ocean  On our moonlight drive

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim stops, shrugs. Ray looks at him a long beat. Intense  eyes, the manner of a man who knows what he wants and can be stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow!... Y'know man those are hot  lyrics -- really hot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased) ...could you write the music for  that down, if we went over to your  place, could you write that on your  organ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding! I could fly. You  wrote that? You got others?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bunch. It's like I'm taking notes  at a rock concert going on inside my  head. I actually hear the music --  the spirit of the wine y'know,  intoxication.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slaps him on the  knee) Man. You got a voice like Chet Baker --  haunted! What the hell happened to  you in the desert? Let's get a rock  and roll band together man and make  a million bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...be great wouldn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking JIM) It's the perfect time man! Two of  the guys outta my band are really  into this. I meditate with them. You  know them... Robbie and John. We  could have it in the can in three  weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey why not, I could write the songs  with you guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stones did it outta the London  School of Economics for Chrissake.  Things are about to explode man. You  can feel it in the air. (points out over the  ocean) Vietnam's right out there. Sides are  being chosen. People wanna fight or  fuck, love or kill, everything's  gonna flame. The planet's screaming  for change, Morrison. Make the myths  man!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim laughs, loves Ray's ardor as they move along the ocea side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There oughta be great orgies man.  Like when Dionysus arrived in Greece,  he made all the women mad, leaving  their homes and dancing off in the  mountains. Great golden copulations  in the streets of LA. (looks at a passing  girl) Hey, do you know her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we call ourselves. "Dionysus"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doors? (facial distaste) That's the most ridiculous... (then) ...you mean the doors in your mind?  Like the Huxley book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Doors of Perception"? Acid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah sure mescaline experiments --  reducing the sugar flow to the brain.  Great book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's from William Blake actually,  the line -- "when the doors of  perception are cleansed -- things  will appear as they truly are..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finishes) -- infinite". It's great, Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where do we start? How do we start?  Where are the girls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rehearsing. You're moving off the  rooftop and in with me and Dorothy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk off, the two of them along the edge of the  Pacific. A dog jumping for a frisbee. The music of MOONLI DRIVE now riffs over the real song now.

dialogues.speaker: DOORS SONG
dialogues.text: Let's swim to the moon  Let's climb thru the tide  Penetrate the evening  That the city sleeps to hide...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first heavy strains of BREAK ON THROUGH driving over DISSOLVE. It sounds bad technically, but it's hot. Random raw screams and shouting. PAM is crosslegged on the floor clapping to the music, number one fan. JIM & DOORS (live) The day destroys the night  Night divides the day  Tried to run  Tried to hide  Break on thru to the other side

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIM straining to make it work, jumping around violent, st not in control. Yet searching. JOHN cutting out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's really square. Let's hip it  up. Jump on your cues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tighten it up. Stay with the beat  Jim. You're dragging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's try it again, come on. I'm  just getting into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on floor) I think it's hot!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (strumming) I still think the lyrics are weird  man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frustrated) I still think it sounds like the  bottom of a fishbowl man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Robbie, aggravated) Then you write one man! We need more  songs anyway. We all gotta go back  and write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're drained, tired, in a large rehersal/living room 3 feet high, fronted by large glass windows looking out at beach at Marina. The room is filled with golden, gorgeous setting sunlight. PAMELA goes to the kitchen with DOROTHY, Ray's Japanese  fiancee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been working on something goes  like this... A minor. (chords his guitar) "You know that it would be untrue  You know that I would be a liar  If I was to say to you  Girl, we couldn't get much higher"  F sharp... chorus  "Come on baby, light my fire  Try to set the night on fire..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie's voice is tinny but something immediate's in the  air, all the radar out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay man there's some good changes  in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got any more lyrics?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gives Jim a page of  lyrics) Some. I call it "Light My Fire". I  figger if I'm gonna compete with  your stuff it's gotta be about earth,  fire or snakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't underestimate Death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah but it sounds like the Byrds  man, we're not folk rock man. How  'bout trying it with a Latin beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we could do the usual verse  chorus verse chorus and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't need a bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we could maybe improvise a  couple piano and guitar solos over  it (kicks in second verse) "The time to hesitate is through" (doesn't have the  second line) Du du duh dud dada . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spontaneous) "No time to wallow in the mire  Try now we can only lose  And our love become a funeral pyre  Come on baby light my fire"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John drumming it, different, more Latin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty good! Pretty neat!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to John) Nice groove, John. Chaka chaka chaka,  then bula burump bula (to Robbie) ...you're right, it could take a  coupla long solos, that's wild man,  like Butterfield did on "East-West" --  really hip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'ever heard Coltrane's "Favorite  Things"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hitting the drums) Yeah -- maybe stretch it out and put  it in 4/4 on bass, 3/4 on guitar and  snare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clicking, excited) Why not! A minor to B minor. Jazz!  That then is jazz! But it needs a  hook. Something. Give me some space.  I need some space. Leave the room  guys. Come on! Go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three excluded Doors head out to the beach like obedi schoolboys while Ray fools with his organ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they go out, JIM hugging ROBBIE's head to his shoulder they feel the excitement of a new song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated at Ray) Guy's obnoxious, man always bossin'  people around! I thought we were  equals!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't we? (to Robbie) That was great Robbie. Whaddaya  thinking about when you play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know. Mostly the fish in my  fish tank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Hey whadya say we take some of that  Tijuana acid and see what kinda  trouble we can get into tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chicks always go for you man. I  get the dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we'll start a religion or plan  a murder or go to Tijuana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatsamatter with you man, what about  Pam, you got the morals of a coyote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you wanna sleep with her John,  just to bug me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell NO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...means "hell yes". She likes you  man, she really does and y'all should.  What's a rock and roll band for man,  if you can't party all night and do  bad things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling from the  house) I GOT IT I GOT IT... GET IN HERE.  HURRY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sieg Heil!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they head back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT on RAY like a schoolmaster cueing them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay here it is. Bach and Rock. Count  it off John

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clicking) 1... 2... 1 - 2 - 3 (crack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It goes. The famous organ intro to LIGHT MY FIRE blends o the room like magic, carrying JIM, ROBBIE, JOHN, DOROTHY, PAMELA along over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A row of NIGHTCLUBS glisten off the hoods of passing traf Marquees announce: THE BYRDS, RED ROOSTER, LOVE, THE HERD TURTLES, CAPTAIN BEEFHEART. The CLUBS are PANDORA'S BOX, TRIP, CIRO'S, BIDO LITO'S, GAZZARRI'S, THE EXPERIENCE... Headlights and neon intercut with: DOCUMENTARY TYPE SHOTS of TEENAGERS, HIPPIES, LONGHAIRS,  running summer rampant, banging tambourines. COPS busting kids against cars on the street as PARENTS go by rolling their windows. The action was on the street. LIGHT MY FIR carries over the montage.

dialogues.speaker: DOORS SONG
dialogues.text: You know that it would be untrue etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (last session) The music was new black polished  chrome and came over the summer like  liquid night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "THE DOORS -- BAND FROM VENICE" on the marquee... moving  down to a motley crew of TEENAGE GIRLS, underage, trying get past the BOUNCER. The sounds of BREAK ON THROUGH carr past when the doors open and close admitting a SAILOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (approaching, to 2nd  girl) Is that horny motherfucker in the  black pants here tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IDs! IDs! Can't get in without an  I.D..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh please. I forgot my I.D.. I'm on  the list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgot my list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BREAK ON THROUGH blasting out at us from a sleazehole --  half full -- BIKERS, SAILORS, HOOKERS, a baseball game on the TV. A dance floor the size of a bed, the DOORS on a t platform above the bar, London newspapers on the wall. JIM & DOORS (live) We chased our pleasures here  Dug our treasures there  Can you still recall the time we  cried  BREAK on through to the other side  (3)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some groupies have formed a small fan club at the base of the stage, muscling past PAM, but most people ignore them drinking, arguing, dancing to their own fuckbeats. Possib this has something to do with the fact that JIM sings wit his back to all of them. JOHN looking over furious at RAY who mutters under the mu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn around Jim! Come on let 'em in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found an island in your arms  A country in your eyes  Arms that chained us, eyes that lied (CHORUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim jumps around violently to the front, getting the atte of all. Rubbing his leather pants against the mike stand, leaning against it, not yet comfortable with the extrover side of himself, eyes closed, but starting to enjoy it. H sings to Pam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JERRY, the ex-vice cop manager who runs the joint, can't  understand the appeal, talking to JIM and ROBBIE who are  packing and hauling their equipment out. DOROTHY is there

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (innocently) So Jerry... do we get paid for this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring her) What shit, "day destroys the night",  "crawl back in your brain", "go  insane". What do people wanna pay  money to hear that shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explains it, gentle) The greater the suffering, the more  terrible the events, the greater the  pleasure Jerry. They want it, it's  catharsis. Like the ancient Greeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) We're in Los Angeles punk, how would  you know, they like your pants,  they're not listenin' to you, what  the hell they see in you I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) But they understand Jerry. All our  real desires are unconscious and  unseen. . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scratching his head) ...you're the weirdest fuckin' guy I  ever...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You love us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love ya. You got two more shows to  do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera gliding across the small crowded smokey room to RA and JOHN in conversation with a slick Beverly Hills MANAG type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I got some real tight record  company connections, just leave it  to me man, I'll take you guys all  the fuckin' way, you blew my mind  out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah right, but what about the music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey the music? I love it man, that's  why we're talking right? Some of  it's a little on the dark side though.  Ya know ya oughta get some tunes  like Herman's Hermits stuff -- "Mrs.  Brown you got a lovely daughter".  That shit goes right to the radio  man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh. Well, how 'bout gettin' us  some real equipment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I sign you guys to a five  year management contract and you got  it all. Equipment. Demo. A truck  WITH roadies. Three, maybe four  percent record deal. Wherever ya  want to go babe, trust me, I'll get  you there. Whatd'ya say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exchanging looks  with John) We'll have a band meeting. The four  of us do everything unanimously or  we don't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The musketeers. I'm touched. But  lemme tell you something -- loyalty  don't pay the bills. Think about it.  Call me tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives Ray a card, leaving, crossing to Jim and PAM tal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ray) What a sleaze! Man, Jim's gotta start  facing the crowd if he's gonna be  the front man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's just getting his confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never does what we rehearsed.  What's the point of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does it feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pam on payphone calling her friends to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...make sure you get Barb and Sue  Anne to come. And tell them to ask  for Jim!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MANAGER on his way out leaning into Jim's face, slyly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, how old are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, twenty one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, you're a gold mine, I'll make  it quick and to the point and if you  repeat it I'll deny it -- drop these  guys, I'll put you with some real  musicians, your voice, your looks,  that's what'll sell records, we'll  make a million bucks. A year. Goodbye.  Call me. I'm right. He gives Jim a  card and goes. Pam disgusted with  the type, Jim laughs, likes the guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like a man wears his soul on his  face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming over) "Whiskey's" next, I can feel it in  my bones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still think the lyrics are weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONTAGE EFFECT -- Jim sings "A Little Game" on the Fog st Super over WHISKEY sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU moving down -- the "LOVE" is on the marquee at the fam WHISKY A GO GO as we move down to see JIM, PAM, and the D Jim jumps through the TEEMING TRAFFIC (horns, anger) righ in front of a COP CAR, crossing to a long line of teenage FANS dying to get into the club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ray, innocently) Jesus Ray, every girl out there wanted  to fuck me, I could feel it for the  first time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right on stud. But you better watch  out for the guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the band) Guys, I'm serious about the desert,  we still gotta deepen man, we gotta  take some peyote -- all of us  together, we got one more stage to  go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know man, fucks up my playing.  I been playing music for 10 years  man and this is the first time in my  whole damned life I ever played it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you satisfied?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you get off my case! I'm never  doing acid again. Too many bad trips  man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not acid John, it's peyote.  It's a bonding ceremony. It's got to  be more... more... more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm into TM man. I promised my guru...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to! I want to! I'm ready.  Let's go to the desert... do the  peyote, the good peyote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to girl in line) Who's on now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (withering look, very  hip) "Love".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Arthur Lee's cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're the best... better'n the  Beatles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean the Marx Brothers of music,  we could blow 'em away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GIRLS looking at each other like who is this jerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doors... We're up the street at  the Fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter from the GIRLS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contempt) The Doors. I heard of you. That's  the dumbest name. I wouldn't go to  the Fog if you paid me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah what would you do for money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go Jim, come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile DENSMORE is hitting up on GIRL 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you don't have a phone number?  What do you mean you don't have a  phone number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a phone number. So give  me your number then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie is doing his imitation of a shrimp for ANOTHER GIR who's laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intrigued, to Jim) Well, would you leave my name at the  door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I don't know. What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caprice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caprice? That's the dumbest name I  ever heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look between Jim and Caprice. Pamela pulling Jim away,  gives the girl a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! I am the Lizard king. I can do  Anything! Raise your hands if you  understand! Alive, any of you alive --  let's take a poll -- how many of you  know you're really alive!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd giggles. Jim climbs a pole, yells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one? Raise your hands c'mon man...  let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the crowd. A few raise their hands, smile. We IRIS in on the Doors suddenly -- a strange sound -- RE IRIS on Jim -- feeling it now. The peyote. JIM's POV -- Pam irising out. This strange sound in his e a rattle of an Indian gourd, similar to what we heard in car in Arizona when Jim was a boy. Now a distant Indian d beating. The beginning strains of THE END dribble in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dented RED CHEVROLET fishtails on a dry mudflat, whippi up dustdevils. They're all LAUGHING (strange noise) -- in a circle somew on the edge of a precipice in deep arroyos and magnificen rocks and cacti... A football huddle of faces - RAY, JOHN, ROBBIE, JIM -- th four DOORS... laughing with the first mad impulse of the  peyote. PAM is vomiting her brains out as DOROTHY tries to comfor her on the edge of a cliff... Jim panthers up the dune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody having a good time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hug. She throws up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...awright, pretty good, it gets  better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim holds his head. Feels the ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOA!! It's fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUMP CUTS: Jim and Pam are touching each other. Face. Sha Sand falls from Pam's hand. Jim turns to hawk at a bird.  "Hawk! Hawk!" Then Pam is dancing alone on the dune. Abruptly Jim is back in the circle with the Doors in a se torn between them and Pam. EXTREME CLOSEUPS of their face their eyes, the tensions of the trip tearing apart their  teeth as they go from the laughing to the dangerous part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the serpent appears, his head  is ten feet long and five feet wide.  He has one red eye and one green  eye. He's deadly and he's seven miles  long. As he moves -- on his scales  is written all the history of the  world, all people, all actions, all  of us our little pictures on the  scales, God it's big! -- and it's  eating as it moves all the time,  devouring, digesting consciousness,  power, a monster of energy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John shutters -- as does Robbie and Ray. Jim seems posses

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must kiss the snake on the tongue,  if it senses our fear, it will eat  us instantly. But if we kiss it  without fear, the snake will take us  through the garden and out the gate.  To our freedom -we must ride this  snake. To the end of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. He has instilled a flux of fear in the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm fucked up. I'm not  thinking right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fucked up John. Go with it,  confusion is the sound of creation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should see your eyes right now,  you're death. Look at your eyes --  you're crazy man, you look crazy.  You scare me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no no John John. God is crazy  too. God is part insane as well as  sane. Not in control all the time.  Dionysus was the God of the wine. He  made ecstasy but he also made madness.  Madness is all right. That's what  you want, isn't it, isn't it? Where's  that joint?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying) I get scared thinking of all the  choices inside. I could go. I could  stay. I can live anywhere. I could  die now if I wanted. It's limitless  choice... and no one cares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Die Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wandering in) I don't know what I am. I'm on the  cusp of Sagittarius and Capricorn.  Sagittarius is wild and Capricorn  domestic and safe, so I don't know  which one to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim looking at her, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the same lens) Oh my God, the light, it's so  beautiful Ray. Can you see it...  it's all one... honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray has his head buried in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in pain man. I want something  from the peyote. I feel the universe  functioning perfectly but I'm still  perfectly locked inside myself.  Instead of Oneness, I feel total  Isolation. Aloneness. Fear... Pain...  Jim, all I feel is pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pain makes me feel more alive Ray.  Pain is meant to wake us up. People  try to hide their pain but they're  wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel Lust. I want to fuck everything  I can, and I know it will never be  enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Pam wants you. (normal) You're a good Catholic John, you  want it so you can feel guilty about  it... Fuck death away John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel Fear... so bad I just numb  out all my feelings. I'm afraid of  my father, I'm afraid of Yahweh... I  wish I could play my guitar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should kill your father  Robbie. He tried to kill you. Kill  him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so fucking scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're Alive! It's beautiful!  Fear, pain, lust, we've got to know  all our feelings before we can come  out the other side free men. Don't  feel ashamed of yourselves, don't  let society destroy your reality.  Our freedom's the only thing worth  dying for, it's the only thing worth  living for!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes Ray and Robbie's hands, his voice calming them,  reform the circle. John hesitant. Not all will enter the  gates at evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold sweats) I'm not gonna make it man. I'm scared  Jim, I'm still scared. Blindness is  coming on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then use us John, use our strength,  it's us four now, a tribe of warriors,  everything we have comes from the  same source, the great Creator of  Being. Trust him, trust us. Ride the  snake. . . I promise you I will be  with you till the end of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulling John into the circle, bonding, their four heads s to the desert floor, Jim making wild Indian sounds, deep- throated "shoooh... shoooh"... now humming a song from th desert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wild love went riding... mmmmmm.  She rode all the day. She ride to  the devil. And ask for him to pay...  shooo shoooo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The OTHERS join in his chant, the four rising and falling like a collective breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ad lib) ...she went to the desert she went  to the sea Joseph we did see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Jim breaks and rises out of the circle. Ray, Rob John, all looking at him. The same need. Pamela, the  desperation of her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) ...I'm lying to you. I am scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes, his boots in the sand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, where are you going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking back) I'll be back. I gotta go alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela calling from another dune, far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim! Jim... come here, dance... don't  go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His POV -- of her, receding. She screams for him. He's in pain. Cannot help her. A BIRD of prey in the sky. Jim moving across a lunar landscape. SPECIAL EFFECT: The is black like night or else white in a black sky. Voices the distance. "Jim, where are you going?" A mother's voic a father's voice.

dialogues.speaker: DOORS SONG
dialogues.text: Can you picture what will be  So limitless and free  Desperately in need of some stranger's hand in a desperat land  Lost in a Roman wilderness of pain and all the children a insane: waiting for the summer rain

dialogues.speaker: DESERT
dialogues.text: JIM, 4, in the back of a car in the desert -- looking bac At the overturned truck, the bodies in the road... at the older Indian looking at him... finally at the dying India his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere. The child alone. On the living room floor. Dra his sketches in a book. MOM's feet moving past -- then DA feet. We may sense a subtle shift in mood when the parent come in -- from the boy's eyes which never leave the sket he is drawing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OLD WOMAN is beckoning to him from an opening in the f of the mountain... then she's gone. JIM bounds towards the crevice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is in an isolated cathedral of rocks. The CRONE, mutte leaving through another crevice. Suddenly a MOUNTAIN LION visible, stretched hugely across a rock. It growls  ferociously, upset, and suddenly shoots out the back of t cave. Silence. Jim, thunderstruck, gaping. A gallery of ancient INDIAN  PETROGLYPHS surround him on all sides. Curious, oblong  figures, buffalo, sacred deer and bear, creatures of the  hunt; hunters and their weapons, rain clouds, masked deit proclaiming the answers to the Mysteries, the story of  Creation. Camera weaving up to see one of the faces of the deities staring at him from the wall -- an eagle's face...

dialogues.speaker: DOORS SONG
dialogues.text: There's danger on the edge of town  Ride the King's highway  Weird scenes inside the gold mine  Ride the King's highway west, baby The sound of a rattle -- "shichishichi" -- he realizes he being watched. By what? He whips his eyes everywhere. A l LIZARD perches on a boulder assesses him calmly, tatters a former skin clinging to its throat, spits a forked tong and drills its black pearly eyes into his skull... Now th sound of the Bull-Roarer, whipping the air, announcing th appearance of the shaman. Jim's struck with an overwhelming sense of... awe... anci mysteries. He turns. The lizard is looking at him. The GHOST of the DEAD INDIAN is also looking at him. We a looking at JIM from its point of view -- a blur of light, some headdress, a sense of skins... music drops back, no  lyrics... the voice is old, familiar, possible Spanish de dialect or huararchi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you are a prince among white men,  yet you are a warrior among us. You  are ready now. Go out "walk with the  pain of the world, travel to the end  of the wind" -- and change it for  all men as you were born to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voice, the pretense, -- the glow too quickly fades -- leaving Jim so alone, not sure what he has heard, yet he  knows he has heard, and he knows he has seen -- and once have seen, it will never be the same again. His eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIM exits the cave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSE on JIM'S EYES as he continues with THE END.

dialogues.speaker: DOORS SONG
dialogues.text: Ride the snake  Ride the snake, to the lake  The ancient lake  The snake is long, seven miles  Ride the snake  He's old, and his skin is cold Camera pulling out from his eyes. There's something diffe tonight. Something in the air. His eyes are open, he's fa outward, gripping the mike for his life, hair falling in face, dripping sweat, we sense all his soul concentrated what he has to say. Cliques of GROUPIES have staked claims at the foot of the stage, eyes fucking him as he writhes, spreading his legs Every twitch, every moment he sucks out the tension on th musical interludes generates a whip of a reaction in his  audience. Nobody is moving in the club. The DANCERS are still, the GO GIRLS in their white plastic boots and dresses hang  motionless in their gilded cages. Even the WAITRESSES hav stopped, frozen with their trays, denying something is go to happen. PAMELA, DOROTHY... JERRY from the Fog, also the manager o this place, watches from the balcony, shaking his head,  doesn't understand. Panning to two RECORD TYPES with him JAC HOLZMAN, distinguished six footer, suit, and PAUL  ROTHCHILD, funky, pigtailed, ex-con, early 30s. JIM & DOORS The west is best (2)  Get here and we'll do the rest  The blue bus is calling us (2)  Driver where you taking us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band has come together fully now. ROBBIE'S fingers sl across the trembling strings, staring at the ceiling,  wandering around the darkened portions of stage left, he  feels Jim -- echoes him back with his flamenco-blues guit JOHN on drums, reading Jim's moods, throws in the spontan and violent riffs that keep it savage. He literally tortu Jim's ears with his drums. And RAY, concentrated with his nodding head like a big  flamingo over his keyboard, mixing it up, throwing curves yet also -- and more delicately -- torturing Jim with the messianic organ sounds that shriek in his ears. There is  something of Merlin in Ray -- the alchemist knowing how t play Jim. And JIM -- "that sneaky silent lithe flowing flexing anim ready at last to share both his body and his soul with th world, to live out the words of the Indian prophet... to  lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The killer awoke before dawn  He put his boots on  He took a face from the ancient  gallery  And he walked on down the hall

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks over up from his board, catches Robby with a 'w this?' look... They go with it, improvising... Jim clutching the mike tighter, seeking solace in its arm it all hangs in the air as if he doesn't have any idea wh he's going to say next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He went to the room where his sister  lived  And he paid a visit to his brother  And then he went on down the hall...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela sensing something is coming... the AUDIENCE... Jer the go-go dancers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he came to a door, And he looked  inside "Father?" "Yes, son?" "I want  to kill you".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASH -- A FATHER'S FACE, any face, older, any man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother... I want to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASH -- A MOTHER'S FACE, any face, older, a woman

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AAAAAAAGGGGGGGHHHHHHH  YOOOOOUUUUUUUUUU!!!!! FUCK YOU ALL  NIGHT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SCREAMS primal, pure Jim -- Indian savagery ripped fr the depths of his soul, of his pain -- bouncing off the  walls... As the AUDIENCE gasps, shocked, stunned... As the guitar hits a high, horrid reverb, JIM in slightly SLOW MOTION suddenly tightens his backbone as if electroc and shoots violently backwards, hitting the floor like a  puppet cut from his string -- we sense Jim himself has cr a barrier now, gone into yet another stage of his perform a stage from which he can never return. Like the gunfight who has killed his first man. RAY sees it instantly where it's going, hits the organ! R and John follow. the instruments EXPLODE all at once tryi to bury Jim in his primal unmistakeable scream. The CLUB in shock. Tribal taboo broken in one instant. Je exploding off the balcony toward the stage... Pamela, extremely moved and impressed, and Dorothy... the go girls, as jaded as they come, are stunned tension... t groupies love it. Jim has jumped up now, dancing an Indian war dance around the mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on baby take a chance with us  (X3)  And meet me in the back of the blue  bus  Doona blue rog onna blue bus  Doona blue yeah!  Come on yeah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIM is being muscled out the door by JERRY, livid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NOBODY'S GONNA FUCK THEIR MOTHER ON  MY STAGE! YOU'RE OUTTA HERE. You  don't ever come back to play, you  don't ever come back to drink --  You're DEAD ON THE STRIP!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ranting back at him) Kill the father, fuck the mother,  kill the father, fuck the mother --  that's what I'm into! That's what  I'm into!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry pinning Jim to the wall,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You -- MORRISON! You're fucking filthy  twisted perverse punk, get back to  your fucking sewer!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly smiling) You have the face of a pig man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost in the melee, RAY and JOHN springing Jim back from l death

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JERRY JERRY... He was talking about  Oedipus! GREEK TRAGEDY!! It's ART!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FUCK ART!! GET THE FUCK ART OUT!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pushing, shoving, scrambling. Past a long-haired JOURNALI yelling into a payphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEVER SEEN ANYTHING LIKE THE DOORS --  NEVER!! GET A PHOTOGRAPHER DOWN HERE.  "ROLLING STONE'S GOTTA SEE THIS!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they rumble by him, all yelling at once. Into the stre EXT. ALLEY & STAIRCASE OUTSIDE WHISKY - THAT NIGHT The DOORS go sailing out, followed by one of their drums, JOHN and ROBBIE restraining Jim from going back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TAKE A LONG LOOK OLD MAN. WE ARE THE  FUTURE. WE ARE THINGS TO COME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FUCK YOU... YOU'RE FUCKING DEAD!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanting to come after Jim but restrained now by the RECOR MOGULS, HOLZMAN and ROTHCHILD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Jerry, cool it, cool it...  he's a kid, it's a song about dying,  changing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAC HOLZMAN pushing past to Ray. Pamela separating Jim  visually from Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to RAY and ROBBIE) We'll never work again man. The Mafia  controls all these clubs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ray and Robbie) Quite a night! Hi, I'm Jac Holzman.  I own Elektra Records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knows the name) Oh sure, hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holzman pauses, a dramatic presence, six foot two, impecc dressed, he knows the weight of his words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen... I think if you could just  put what you did in there on record,  we could really have something...  and we could make a lot of money...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hangs there. Impossible words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Robbie sharing looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to ROTHCHILD  coming up) Yeah... and Rothchild here was born  to be your producer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recognizing Paul) Hey, the guy that did Butterfield!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertold Brecht, cabaret and rock.  Give me a fucking break. You guys  are amazing! Let's go make a record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ray, pointing  back at Jerry) Hey, is that asshole gonna pay us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) Why don't you go inside and ask him  Jim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strains of LIGHT MY FIRE cross the cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four-track TAPE SYSTEM is rolling.

dialogues.speaker: DOORS SONG
dialogues.text: You know that it would be untrue  You know that I would be a liar  If I was to say to you  Girl, we couldn't get much higher Camera moving fast thru the control room, past the ENGINE (BRUCE BOTNICK), taciturn, 20's, the PRODUCER (PAUL ROTHC in pig heaven, and the owner JAC HOLZMAN in his blue suit watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Bruce, you feel it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm having big fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jac) I got goosebumps Jac. This is history  going down here. An album of killer  music in six days... six days...  unreal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera moving fast past a smiling PAM watching, out to th DOORS on the floor, jamming... on to JIM in the vocal boo headphone to his ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on baby, LIGHT MY FIIIRRRREEEE!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The song, now fully -- orchestrated, rolling on over the  following MONTAGE:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after song) Pretty good! Pretty neat!

dialogues.speaker: DAY, (1967)
dialogues.text: LIGHT MY FIRE continues. DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE of the "Human Be-In", the "Summer of  Love" -- swarming FLOWER CHILDREN, WAR PROTESTORS. A staged 16mm. grainy shot of JIM and PAMELA, RAY and DOR JOHN, ROBBIE and their TWO NEW GIRLFRIENDS wandering thru the CROWD sharing the spirit. Pam and Jim fool around --  laughing -- tickling each other for the home movie camera shot by Ray... Pam is goofy, makes funny faces, teases hi running a flower under his nose, thru his hair, then trip him. He chases her across the lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CROWD is "beautiful" -- candles, incense sticks, flow vibes of peace and love. The instrumental of "Light My Fi is playing, but only three DOORS are on stage till Jim co swinging across on a rope like tarzan all the way across stage -- then drops down, rebounds lithely and hits the m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) The time to hesitate is through  No time to wallow in the mire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIM swandives into the stoned crowd with the mike at the  instrumental section, a colored spotlight flecking him, G kiss him. The guys want to be him, the girls want him -- he knows it, teasing and tantalizing them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try now we can only lose  And our love become a funeral pyre  Come on baby, light my fire  Try to set the night on  FIIIIIIIIIRE!!!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BODYGUARDS running in to pull him out as he's tossed, lik limp god, over the heads of the crowd, rolling like a buo on a rocking sea, from hand to hand, Dionysus, devoured l from limb by the "little girls". PAMELA watching from the side curtain. ALABAMA SONG (WHISKY BAR) now kicks in with its comic,  Brechtian strain as we:

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screaming FANS chase the DOORS to a commercial airplane,  scribbling autographs. One of the GIRLS smacking JIM on t lips as he laughs, her cameras clicking. PAMELA shooting home movie of it, pushed aside by the crowd, rescued by R and the new young manager, BILL SIDDONS...

dialogues.speaker: DOORS SONG
dialogues.text: Oh show me the way to the next whisky bar  Oh don't ask why  Oh don't ask why

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The City as seen by:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIM'S face pressed to the window, PAMELA next to him hugg each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (real close, hugging  her) I don't mind dying in a plane crash,  a smile on my face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting his food) As compared to what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't want to go out slow --  brain tumor, botulism. I want to  feel what it's like, cause death is  only going to happen to you once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to die ever, what a  weird thing to say.

dialogues.speaker: DOORS SONG
dialogues.text: For if we don't find the next whisky bar  I tell you we must die  I tell you  I tell you  I tell you we must die

dialogues.text: A LIMOUSINE pulling up in front of the Ed Sullivan Marque The sidewalk is mobbed with FANS, mostly YOUNG GIRLS.

dialogues.speaker: DOORS SONG
dialogues.text: Oh moon of Alabama  We now must say goodbye  We've lost our good ol mama  We must have whiskey oh you know why

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIM looking out at the MOB with the other DOORS and PAMEL The look on his face is ironic. His POV -- the YOUNG GIRLS' FACES, arms grasping at the  windows like tentacles of a poisonous hydra, their faces  deformed by SILENT SCREAMS (we hear faint strangled shrie below the song)... POLICE and SECURITY pressing them back linking arms to clear a path for the Doors.

dialogues.speaker: DOORS SONG
dialogues.text: Show me the way to the next little girl  Oh don't ask why  Oh don't ask why The GIRLS crying hysterically as Jim lazily, leopardly, m across the CROWD, almost like Oswald waiting for the Ruby bullet but with that sweet, pleasant smile on his face, d glasses concealing...

dialogues.text: (faint) Oh Jimmmmm, pleeeaaase look, I looove  youuuuu, Jimmmmmm, pleeeeeaase,  Jimmmmm, here, sign miiiine... take  a picture Jim?... Jim, Jim, oh please  look at me Jim!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their voices distorting. A GIRLCHILD squeezing thru the c with the fatal bullet. In slightly SLOW MOTION, Jim seein her come... as she glues herself hip to hip, lip to lip w Jim, her hands clawing at his leather pants. It takes TWO COPS to peel her off. Pamela furious. Jim is gracious wit everyone, signs patiently, talks, kisses, shakes hands wi the boys, lets them touch his hair, his body, poses for a picture, seems to like it.

dialogues.text: For if we don't find the next little girl  I tell you we must die  I tell you  I tell you  I tell you we must die

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nervous PRODUCER, HERB, leading "MR. SULLIVAN" thru t corridor to the Doors' DRESSING ROOM past several "ACTS"  getting ready to go on... animals, tumblers, a soprano  wailing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right this way Mr. Sullivan. They're  called "the Doors". They got the  number one single in the country --  "Light Your Fire".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Light Your Fire"? Is that sooo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look pretty grungy but we're...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bedlam. MAKE-UP ARTISTS pancaking the faces of the DOORS the nightmare coming true. RAY in a white suit with too m pinstripes. ROBBIE a spearmint turtleneck, beads, long  sideburns, JOHN in red velveteen head to foot with a tie- splotch on the front of it. Their hair's being violated e by a nervous gay black HAIR DESIGNER to make them totally self-conscious and nervous about their first live TV  appearance -- all except JIM who remains in his signature black leather with the silver navajo belt and shiny spang watching a portable TV... A GIRL leaving his side, crossi Pamela. Eye contact between them speaks of Pamela's jealo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignant) You're gonna cut it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doing John) No, I'm going to worship it. What  kind of shampoo are you using?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kind you get in hotels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamper yourself sweetheart, you don't  want split ends, you're a celebrity  now. (moving to Ray) You have very serious-serious hair,  it needs to rebel. I'll give it a  tinge of something freaky.

dialogues.text: I'm dying Ray. I wasn't kidding.  Maybe you were. But I'll tell you  something, it's not about these  desires you have man, or money, or  these records, it's about breaking  through wasn't it? You just lost  something man. (to all) We all lost something boys. We lost  something.

dialogues.text: I don't think so Jim. There's a bigger  picture here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small smile flickers Jim's face as he picks up the smal TV and like a quarterback, hurls it, spinning end over en from his corner of the Control Room towards Ray and Rothc and the Doors. They dive for the floor as it smashes to b into the wall behind the tape machines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Just kidding... (turning to Pam) Hi Pam. Just watchin' some TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems pleased to distract his anger into her. She does seem to notice anything unusual going on. The Doors silen feeling Jim's rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pathetic) I wanted you to find us Jim. It meant  nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others all look away embarrassed. This is certainly a moment the ordinary partner might turn away from Pamela, tears running, but her pathacy, her inability to deal wit pain is precisely what moves Jim the most -- a side of hi in her -- an ultimate weakness she has, he shares. As he  goes to her, puts his arms gently around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright honey, it's gonna be  alright. You're my girl and that's  the way it's always gonna stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snuggles him, zoned) Really...?

dialogues.text: Rothchild looking to Botnick and to Ray. But the real loo the unforgiving one, is from Jim to Ray who feels it.  Rothchild douses the lights in the studio.

dialogues.text: Right on Jimbo.

dialogues.text: Overdubb of DOORS SONG SOFT PARADE - Jim's VOICE booming  thru the studio.

JIM & DOORS Can you give me sanctuary  I must find a place to hide  A place for me to hide...

Magic's  suddenly in the air once more as we jump stanzas to: JIM & DOORS Catacombs, nursury bones  Winter women  Streets and shoes, avenues  Leather riders selling shoes (The monk bought lunch) Successful hills are here to stay  Everything must be this way  Gentle street where people play  Welcome to the soft parade

dialogues.text: But Jim's voice has now gone off key, floating carefree,  drifting -- drifting away. ROTHCHILD chuckles, philosophically. The Doors in control booth start leaving. Morrison "falls" off  the stage at least every other  performance. "The Soft Parade" album  only confirms the plasticity of their  approach. Songs like "Touch Me" and  "Follow Me Down" are not the Doors  we once knew. So the question is:  Why am I here? Are funerals  entertainment?
